title: Coronation Street's most harrowing episodes ever as Sinead Tinker dies in darkly realistic scenes
text:

Sinead Tinker will die next week in some of Coronation Street's most harrowing scenes ever after a long struggle with cervical cancer.

The scenes don't shy away from the dark realism of a terminal cancer sufferer's final days and shows Sinead, played by Katie McGlynn, drifting in and out of consciousness as she says goodbye to her family and friends.

Corrie have worked closely with charities Mummy's Star and Jo's Cervical Cancer Trust during Sinead's storyline in order to make the storyline as realistic as possible.

Throughout the two episodes, lasting an hour and a half in total, viewers will watch Sinead struggle with the pain as husband Daniel tries his best to stay strong for her and comfort his wife.

In one particularly poignant scene, Sinead delivers a monologue to her son Bertie in the form of a video message, knowing that he won't remember her face when he is older.

Boss Iain MacLeod said that ensuring that Sinead’s death wasn’t "quick" was intentional.

"It felt like the respectful way of doing it, the most interesting way of doing it and the least "soapy" way of doing it was just to be in there and see the difficulties, really," he said.

"Experience the moments of laughter, the moments of warmth and let it tell its own story and take its own time."

He then added: "So yeah, it was a conscious decision not to fast forward that. I also feel like after you've told a story for two years, 18 months, it would be remiss to gallop through the end, actually.

"I think we're a bit immune to the realities [of death] and a bit scared of looking at it."

Sinead manages to forgive Daniel after discovering he kissed Bethany and hugs him tight in bed as they consider their lost future, telling him that she would have liked to have had four boys with him and live in a thatched cottage.

Vicar Billy visits her and she hands him a note with all of her funeral plans written on it and the pair become involved in a discussion about the afterlife, and whether there is one at all.

Sinead's family later visit her while she is gravely ill, with her mum in tears as she apologises for being a "bad mother".

Realising that she is in her last hours, Sinead asks her family to leave and return in the morning - knowing that she won't see them again.

(Image: ITV)

Alone with Daniel again, she makes him promise not to go off the rails for Bertie's sake. She then begins telling him to bathe Bertie properly and not using a flannel, which Daniel admits he is scared about getting wrong.

However he agrees and when Daniel reads Bertie a bedtime story, Sinead dies quietly.

The final powerful scene of the episodes show Daniel returning home after taking a walk with his son, following his wife's death, and standing in their apartment alone.

He manages to pull himself together and takes his son for a bath.

Speaking about whether Daniel would change in the aftermath of Sinead's death, actor Rob said: "He's got the baby to focus on, but in terms of himself there won't be any, because that's the next stage of the story.

"She's told him all these things and that he needs to forgive himself and all of that but it's all been caught up in the death.

(Image: ITV)

"He has to now unpick all of that and take all the meaning and the messages from what she was saying to him and actually apply them.

"But the trauma and the shock of it, you kind of get away from that as quickly as possible. So there will be, but it will take a bit of time to implement it."

After watching the episodes for the first time, actress Katie said that it was like seeing a loved one die.

(Image: ITV)

"It is sad because we've developed the character for six and a half years and I feel like I know her and she's gone now," she said. "So watching her final days - it doesn't feel like I'm watching myself, it feels like I'm watching her.

"It's really sad, I feel like someone's died."

*Sinead's final scenes air on Coronation Street for half an hour on Thursday 24 October and Friday 25 October for an hour
description: Katie McGlynn's character will die next week in upsetting realistic scenes
